Wave propagation in microtubule-based bio-nano-architected networks: A lesson from nature
Hamid Jafari, Mohammad Reza Hairi Yazdi, Mir Masoud Seyyed Fakhrabadi ∗
School of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Keywords: Microtubule Architected structure Bloch’s theorem Dispersion relation Bandgap
a b s t r a c t
Microtubules, bio-polymeric hollow tubes forming entangled radial networks from the nucleus to the cell membrane, are considered the main part of the cytoskeleton providing mechanical stiffness, organization and shape for the cytoplasm of the eukaryotic cells and playing substantial roles in some cellular processes such as mechanotransduction, cell division, intercellular transports, internal organization of the cell components, etc. In all of the mentioned functions, the network structure of the microtubules has the main responsibility proving the importance of more in-depth studies of their mechanical properties. This paper addresses the elastic wave propagation in various two-dimensional microtubule-based bio-nano-architected periodic networks to analyze their dynamic characteristics for possible further utilizations. The study starts with selecting a proper beam model for a single microtubule, as proved by previous experiments, and continues with creating ten widely used periodic structures, namely square, triangle, triangle–square, triangle–diamond, negative Poisson’s ratio, semi-honeycomb, star–honeycomb, zig-zag, hexagram, and Sierpinski triangle, thereof. To obtain the dispersion curves, finite element models are developed for both individual and networked microtubules, and the phononic band structures are calculated based on Bloch’s theorem. The results reveal the possibility of designing bandgaps in specific ranges for the low- and high-frequency bio-filter applications depending on the topologies of the selected unit cells as well as the considered periodicities. This application helps researchers control the ways to absorb some unwanted or hazardous vibrations using architected periodic structures and, thanks to the higher biocompatibility resulted from their biomaterial origin, the networks can be applied in next-generation nano-biomechanical instruments such as implantable biosensors.

. Introduction
Due to the high demands for daily-increasing capabilities of novel ystems, engineers are curiously searching for new materials, designs, r phenomena in order to inspire or utilize them to promote the level f human life. To realize this goal, they recently have focused on metaaterials on one side and biotechnology, which is thoroughly inspired y nature’s way of doing things at different scales, on the other side. other nature has her own unique set of atomic and molecular members nd architectures that have been working for centuries and optimized or the superb performance and design over the ages. In this path, scintists have attained to the stupendous building blocks in the nature alled cells having such amazing capabilities that undoubtedly can be onsidered as fantastic factories. However, analyzing their various comonents and studying all the stories behind them are out of the scope of his paper. Therefore, we are going to narrow down our study and focus ainly on the dynamic aspects and phononic properties of one mechancally stable cytoskeleton filament. The cytoskeleton besteads cells to

Some basic human senses such as audition, equilibrioception r tactioception rely on the mechanotransduction and some diseases, anging from deafness to cancer may relate to malfunctioning of this ransduction process. Hence, discovering the mystery behind the intraellular dynamic mechanotransduction procedure through the microubule networks leads to a better understanding of these senses and disases and also opens the doors for developing and fabricating intelligent iomaterials and structures for novel applications in near future. More pecifically, characterization of the phononic and momentum-transport roperties of some microtubule-based meshworks can pave the way to tart understanding and designing biopolymer networks that can transer/filter various signals on different timescales and in different direcions. It is not unlikely that nature has done something similar within ach cell over the billions of years, but now we are aiming to decipher he secrets and reconstruct such a biomimetic architected system in a ottom-up approach starting from single microtubules and extending to he unit cells of larger periodic networks.
The research field of metamaterials, man-made materials with deigned internal structures, is nowadays a very hot research topic and he prevalence of 3D printing techniques has boosted this research area, ore. Periodic architected materials or structures are parts of the bulk edium having periodicity in one, two or three directions with lots of otential and actual applications such as vibration filtering [14] , tunble Poisson’s ratio [15] , low-density [16] , frequency conflation [17] , nd thermal resistance [18] . Among all, one of the significant specifiations of these structures is the possibility of their utilization in conrol and management of wave propagation and vibrational noises that an have many negative [19] and positive aspects [20] in terms of the arious functioning of the mechanical systems. The periodic structures an be designed deliberately to damp some frequency ranges of elastic aves called bandgap areas. Recently, many studies were performed on he macro-scale emission of waves and the techniques to determine the ositions of the bandgaps and increase their areas [21] .
Brillouin is known as the first scientist scrutinizing the wave propaation in two- and three-dimensional periodic structures, systematically n 1953 [22] . Subsequently, several studies were carried out on this ubject with the main purpose of bandgap analysis [23,24] . For this reaon, the effects of different conditions such as damping [25] , in-plane or ut-of-plane deflections [26] , connection type between periodic beams 14] , slenderness ratios, and relative densities [27] were investigated n the attenuation zones. Moreover, researchers numerically showed hat the wave propagation analysis of the 2D structures is actually a
implification of the 3D models [26] . Also, their phononic band strucures extracted from the wave propagation analyses were presented in he literature [27] . According to the band structures, the topologies of he architected materials have significant effects on the filtered frequenies. The configurations of square, hexagonal, Kagome, triangular honycomb [27] , random network [28] , and Sierpinski-carpet [29] have een widely investigated for the mentioned purposes.
As described before, the wave propagation in the biological strucures can play substantial roles in nature and despite such fantastic influnces, this issue has been remained unexplored to a large extent. There re just a few studies in the literature on the band structures of the bioetworks such as spider webs [30] . This phenomenon can be even more mportant if we focus on the bio-building blocks because it seems possile to design the topologies of the unit cells made from the basic comonents in order to have bio-materials with unique desired characterisics. In this line, Koch et al. [31] could build small linear and triangular etworks of the microtubules using the optical tweezers and showed hat the microtubule networks could have different dynamic properties uch as stiffening the structures proved by higher resonance frequenies than the single microtubules. It is worth noting that connecting are microtubules to each other is not easily possible due to their elecrostatic charges however, by using some linkers it is possible [32] . In 991, researchers observed that microtubules extracted from frog eggs rganized themselves in the form of the stable asters by the exploitaion of minus-end motor dynein [33] . Further investigations were done hen to develop the formation process of microtubule patterns in vitro 34] and in silico [35] . In addition, computer simulations proved that arious networks can appear from interactions between similar compoents considering their physical properties, complexity and concentraion [32,35,36] . Hence, microtubules can be connected tightly by minusnd and plus-end motors to form various shapes and geometries and och et al. [31] considered the above mechanism and could connect mirotubules to functionalized optical tweezer beads in order to form small etworks. They also investigated the successful load-bearing, tension, uckling and vibration of the individual microtubules and their netorks, experimentally. Another evidence opening horizons in the posibility of building microtubule networks is their branching during the olymerization and growth [37] . This fact is very similar to the branchng of carbon nanotubes during the growth embarking the field of carbon anotube networks [38] . Thus, based on the experimental results and he concepts of structural dynamics, arranging microtubules in a set to reate specified topologies can be an effective nature-inspired approach o design appropriate architected materials. Hence, in the present paper, e apply the microtubules as the primary elements of ten unit cells of the eriodic structures, namely square, triangle, triangle–square, triangle– iamond, negative Poisson’s ratio, semi-honeycomb, star–honeycomb, ig-zag, hexagram, and Sierpinski triangle. Then, their attenuation zones re calculated and the relations between the bandgap areas and different onfigurations are analyzed. The main contribution of this paper is to o the computational parts of the corresponding experimental activities o help experimentalists design the bio-networks based on some rules eveloped by our computational work and analyze their results much etter.
The paper is formed in four divisions, including this introduction. n Section 2 , the finite element (FE) models of the architected periodic tructures are developed, and the procedure to obtain the equations of otion of a general unit cell is explained. Then, Bloch’s theorem is aplied and the dispersion relation is generated. Section 3 studies the outomes of various configurations in terms of bandgap areas. Moreover, he effects of different periodicities on the bandgap areas are inspected. inally, the closing remarks are summarized in Section 4 .

. Results and discussion
This section covers the dispersion curves resulted from solving q. (11) , numerically. metadata.abstractText: Microtubules, bio-polymeric hollow tubes forming entangled radial networks from the nucleus to the cell membrane, are considered the main part of the cytoskeleton providing mechanical stiffness, organization and shape for the cytoplasm of the eukaryotic cells and playing substantial roles in some cellular processes such as mechanotransduction, cell division, intercellular transports, internal organization of the cell components, etc. In all of the mentioned functions, the network structure of the microtubules has the main responsibility proving the importance of more in-depth studies of their mechanical properties. This paper addresses the elastic wave propagation in various two-dimensional microtubule-based bio-nano-architected periodic networks to analyze their dynamic characteristics for possible further utilizations. The study starts with selecting a proper beam model for a single microtubule, as proved by previous experiments, and continues with creating ten widely used periodic structures, namely square, triangle, triangle–square, triangle–diamond, negative Poisson’s ratio, semi-honeycomb, star–honeycomb, zig-zag, hexagram, and Sierpinski triangle, thereof. To obtain the dispersion curves, finite element models are developed for both individual and networked microtubules, and the phononic band structures are calculated based on Bloch’s theorem. The results reveal the possibility of designing bandgaps in specific ranges for the lowand high-frequency bio-filter applications depending on the topologies of the selected unit cells as well as the considered periodicities. This application helps researchers control the ways to absorb some unwanted or hazardous vibrations using architected periodic structures and, thanks to the higher biocompatibility resulted from their biomaterial origin, the networks can be applied in next-generation nano-biomechanical instruments such as implantable biosensors.
